segments.text: about killer asteroids and comets?
I would beware of spending an awful lot of money on killer asteroid and comet detection.
I don't think that's appropriate.
I think we as a scientific community should avoid raising the scare.
This will always happen, however.
I mean, look at the 1910 comet.
situation, and you've got an analogous situation.
These things develop of their own accord, and in these tight funding times, it's awfully hard to fault the people who stand ready to prey on the public's fears.
But I think as responsible scientists, we can do something.
I would hope that we could keep the expenditures on these things to within reasonable and appropriate limits.
The relationship of the press, or TV, whatever, media, with the AS is certainly a lot different than it was when I was a grad student.
I mean, a reporter at an AS meeting was a real rarity.
Maybe from the local paper, astronomers meet or something, and now there's quite a bit done.
It's really quite a professional operation.
Do you think that this has really helped get astronomers more publicity and reach more public?
Oh, yes.
Oh, yes.
It certainly has.
I mean, you cannot underestimate the effect that Kathy Sawyer's articles on the front page of the Washington Post or the New York Times coverage on its

science section and i guess we had a we were on the front page of the times at our last meeting as well and that's got to be very very helpful and and i think it's helpful in two ways it's helpful because it alerts the congress and the public of the fact that exciting things are going on in science and it's it's something worth doing but i think it's also important for its effect on the field for
pointing out to the practitioners that it's okay to put your name in the papers, and you should be doing more of it, more to communicate, let's say, with the public than we currently are doing.
We cannot disconnect ourselves from the people who are funding us, and as a science, we've been tending to do that.
We used to have a little saying, Iceman and I, and various other people, the planetary game, the Mount Wilson Palomar, funded by Carnegie,
Their attitude was the public be damned.
Yeah.
You know, and obviously we can't do that anymore.
Well, they're now taking public money.
So they have to do this, too.
Oh.
Okay, we're back here with Peter Boyce, and talking about some of the overlaps with some of the old-timers at Lowell.
Now, there were two Slifers, correct?
Yeah.
V.M.
Slifer had already retired from Lowell and was living downtown, but E.C.
V.M., of course, was the person who discovered the galactic recession radial velocities.
Which is often mistakenly attributed to somebody at Mount Wilson.
Yes.
Hubble did organize them, but they were first discovered by V.M.
Slipher, and he would spend three nights on the same exposure at the telescope.
So...
He really had to work to get him.
But E.C.
was a wonderful character.
Tremendous memory.
When I first met him in 63, 64, 65, he would come in and he had all the plates, as I said, organized in cigar boxes.
And if you asked him for...
what Mars looked like in a 1927 opposition.
He said, oh, yeah, that one we had to go to South Africa for.
And we stored that in a corona box.
And he'd go and he'd pick out the box and open it up.
Sure enough, it would be the 1927 plates from South Africa.
And he could pull them out and put them on the viewer and talk about all the things that happened during that year and the growth of the dark areas and the caps and the way it would

uh cloud over and so on so uh it was quite different from any kind of modern library and plate ball and stuff when we tried to use these plates and put densitometers well some of them had densitometer spots and we tried to use those for a study of blue clearing

which is times when you could see surface features in the blue as well as in the red, and found that these densitometer spots were really badly done, so that the whole thing was really not a very firm footing from the standpoint of calibrated photometric scale that you'd like to have it.
But certainly, EC had a tremendous...
library, and most of it just all stored in his memory.

And he would go up with a 24-inch, he'd take a plate, he'd start the exposure, and it would begin to drift out a little bit, and instead of turning the knobs, the slow-motion knobs, to bring the telescope back on, he would just kind of lean against it, you know, and one would think that he had probably better
ability to get that telescope where he wanted and keep it pointed than most modern observers have today.
Bill Sinton was another interesting character and loved gadgets and loved practical jokes too.
Although maybe Larry Frederick was one of the great practical jokes of all time.
I guess Larry was the practical joke.
Anyway, what happened was, I forget the names, but there are two telescopes on Mars Hill, the 24-inch and the 21-inch.
And I think Larry came out.
No, Larry did it.
Larry was observing on the 24-inch.
Which is a refractor or a reflector?
This is the reflector.
not the old telescope.
About 2 or 3 in the morning the Milky Way would rise in the east and we had some poor guy come in from the east coast or maybe even from Europe observing on the 21 inch and this

milky way would begin to rise in the east and larry would kind of wander down the road and poke his head in the 21 inch telescope which is a building which had a roll-off roof and say well you see over there i'm beginning to get a little uh problem with my photometry and and i think i see a cloud bank coming in from the east and the guy would look over and he said oh yeah he said wow that's that's pretty bright i i guess i'll uh just
Larry said, I think I'm going to close up and go home.
And the guy said, I'll do that too.
And he closed up the 21-inch and went home.
Of course, Larry went back and spent the rest of the night taking data.
And he did it for three nights in a row until the guy discovered that maybe this is something else.
And he waited a little longer, and suddenly it was very clear that this was the Milky Way that was sending him home to bed.
And Bill Sinton used to tell that story with the greatest gusto you can imagine.
Or the other one is to...

position people in the dome so when they look out the slit they're looking at sculptor in the south galactic pole and jesus on a high cloud that's right that's another good one um any more alzheimer's lamp one i didn't overlap with but he of course was at lowell observatory for a long time and he was one of the early people to try to bring uh quantitative measurements to uh
to planetary astronomy.
And he never got credit, really, for what he did, because I don't think he published enough.
He wasn't aggressive enough.
And I think there was probably a major feeling among the West Coast astronomers that these upstarts at Lowell were not as good scientists as other people.
Lampman really did a lot of pioneering work in radiometry, did he not?
Tremendous amount.
But he was a nut on instrumentation.
When he died, I think every battery that had ever been bought by Lowell Observatory was there with its...
I mean, every month he would go around all the batteries and the recorders and so forth and measure the voltage and keep a record of it in a notebook.
And so it would start at a volt and a half, say, and then work down and work down.
Finally...
the 1.2 volts that became useless, not enough juice in it.
Well, he put it on a shelf, but he would still measure it every month.
Bill Sinton said he saw notebooks of Lamplins that had battery measurements where the voltages were half a volt and a tenth of a volt.
You know, I think eventually the whole thing must have, the acid must have eaten through and it became worthless.
But apparently there were just rows upon rows of dead batteries.
dead light bulbs were saved also after the filament burned out in the hopes that maybe they could be resurrected.
It's a wild thing.
My hope at that time was, except it would have given Henry a heart attack, was to... Henry who?
Henry Giklis, was to sneak down into the vault where the original Pluto discovery plates were kept and
replace them with plain glass and stow them somewhere else.
So when Henry would bring a visitor down to show them very carefully the original discovery plates of Pluto, he would find plain glass.
But I am absolutely convinced if I'd done that and been found out, it would have been worth my job at Lowell.
When you first got there,
Could you live on the salary?
I mean, Flagstaff's a pretty expensive place, being 166.
And did they pay you enough so you could actually make a living?
I thought so at the time.
They provided me with a house and a major salary of $6,500.
Did you pay your own utilities, or did they provide those?
They provided the utilities.
It was all right.
You know, none of us got rich.
Some of us got rich.
The Slifers got rich on the real estate they had in the town.
And Henry got rich on the cotton.
Cotton?
He had a cotton farm down outside of Phoenix.
But those of us who stuck to the business didn't seem to amass a lot of money.
Amass a lot of money.
Any more old-timer stories?
Hey, what about...
I can tell you a couple on John Hall.
All right.
If you want that.
Sure.
John was the most avid observer that I had almost ever seen.
And it was so important to him to be using the telescope and getting data that he would do that in preference to making sure that his equipment was working right.
And he had to throw away a whole month's worth of dark-run data when he discovered that he hadn't calibrated his instruments.
I thought it was just an example of priorities gone wrong.
But I found him one time chasing an object down as it sank in the west.
And the 72-inch telescope, at that time we'd put a 72-inch mirror in it, had...
You had to put it across the pier, and it was an English mount.
And so when it was setting in the west, it had to be up above the axis.
And so to get to the back end, the business end, you had to really get up high.
I found him on a rickety metal roll-around observing ladder, which was not tall enough.
He was standing on a gray box.
We had several gray boxes around us to various heights to reach the eyepiece.
This gray box was perched on the waist-high observing ladder railing
so that the railing itself was 10 feet over the floor.
He had this foot and a half high box, and he was standing on tiptoes as this object he was looking was setting down into the pine trees on the west.
Well, of course, he was doing one of these Rube Goldberg things one time and fell off it and broke his ribs rather badly.
I guess one of many astronomers who've had accidents like that.
This was before your time, of course, but were there any rumors circulating around the staff at the time about Percival Lowell and his longtime secretary?
Was her name Rixey, somebody or something?
I lived in the old library, and I spent a good long time looking for where the supposed tunnel from the library to Lowell's house, which was basically our front yard,
had been.
I did not see any evidence of the tunnel.
I'm not sure that, given the lack of traffic on the hill, that they would have needed a tunnel.
Yes, there were plenty of rumors.
It is interesting that Lowell got married very late in life, and a couple of days after that happened, his longtime secretary just departed and never returned.
So that was around, huh?
Yes.
Oh, yeah.
Actually, some guys from Lowell, I think Len, whatchamacallit, and somebody else gave a paper on that at the historical section of the Division for Planetary Astronomy one time.
They couldn't find the tunnel either.
They went out and probed for it.
This was in the 70s.
And couldn't find it.
Well, it's very interesting because...

People at Lowell did a lot of things, actually, to try to verify the reality of the canals, including putting one of those little Martian globes that are all around the observatory way up on the hills in the San Francisco peaks and looking at them with the 24-inch to see what they would see.
We actually did suffer a bit from Lowell's
you know, canal scheme.
I think that EC, while not believing in the canals, believed in the network of straight lines very, very, very, very much.
When you were there, how did the townsfolk take to the observatory and the astronomers?
Well, they really liked it.
We had a couple times had an open house that drew a lot of people out to the Anderson Mesa.
And that was really exciting because people would look in, they'd see a globular cluster through the telescope, and they'd just go haywire.
And you realized all over again what got you into astronomy in the first place.
You start telling them how the light's been coming since before the pyramids were built and so on.
The mystery and wonder of it, the public brings that back.
And that's a great thing.
I was just always well received in the town.
I actually did a little weekly show for a little while.
Went down to the coffee shop, and they had a little coffee shop talk show.
And I'd talk a little bit about what was going on at the observatory, and Henry Giklis absolutely went ballistic when he found out.
I did it for three or four weeks, and mentioned something about...
what Henry was doing.
And people around the town didn't know what Henry was doing, even though it was very, very important, just the proper motion survey.
And Henry just put down the law, laid down the law that he was the one that was supposed to be the communication with the town.
And other astronomers were not supposed to talk about what was going on at Lowell.
And it's just such a defeating, self-defeating
Well, that's the way astronomers used to behave.
Yeah.
I think in general was quite true.
And I think, you know, that's the kind of thing we talked about earlier.
I think we suffer from it.
I know when I was a grad student, in fact, even today, people say, you know, what are you doing?
I say, I'm an astronomer.
And they say, but you don't act like an astronomer.
Oh, I know, I know.
I mean, and I think it's an image left over from, now certainly if you go way back, you know, George Aylor and Hale types, they weren't shrinking violets.
But did you find when you were in graduate school that the older astronomers tended to be very much to themselves and not too interested in the public?
That's right.
I was both at Harvard and at Michigan.
That was left to one or two people around the observatory.
And it was definitely not a high priority item.
No, no.
But then again, they weren't so dependent on public money at the time.
And they just didn't realize the importance of keeping the public informed and excited about science.
But anyway, the times at Lowell were very interesting.
It must have been wonderful with Harold Johnson there.
because he had a real screaming fight with a number of people, including somebody was, one director came in, the one before John Hall who lasted just a year.
Who was the director before?
I can't remember.
Bart Boak?
No, that was after.
After.
He lasted only a year, and he went and he cleaned out everything in the attic, and he threw it out the window into a heap on the ground.

And Harold Johnson and the two Slifers, and maybe Lamplin was still alive at the time, they were, as fast as the stuff was being thrown onto the pile, they were grabbing it up and taking it back inside the building.
Waste not, want not.
As a consequence, you know, when I moved in, I moved into Harold Johnson's old office, and there were a lot of stuff still left.
But there's a tremendous amount of
historical material and interesting instruments and things which were no longer used.
Some of the bailing wax and bailing wire and sealing wax contraptions that were heaved out in this fit of clearing out that I think would have been nice to have around.
It made a fine museum for, you know, archaic astronomical instruments.
I mean, you know, I'm just thinking
These young whippersnappers, they don't know what a vacuum tube is.
They don't even know what a 1P21 is.
And we had a whole, John Hall had a whole closet full of them.
Okay.
One more point here.
I was talking with Peter Boyce about the state of planetary astronomy in the 20s and 30s when not only was it held in low repute by a

other astronomers, but also results were few and far between, and probably a lot of that was due to the fact that there was an instrumentation barrier, both as to wavelength and stability for photometry and wavelength for detectors for spectroscopy, and so you were just about to say something about that.
I was saying it's absolutely true that the kind of instrumentation that you use for stellar photometry, by and large, is not very useful for planetary astronomy.
Telescopes, for instance, if you're trying to track a fast-moving asteroid, are hard to point when you're doing photometry on.
So people didn't do photometry on asteroids.
The visible light photometry doesn't tell you a great deal about the asteroids.
You have to get into the infrared to really pick out the different asteroid families.
And the infrared detectors weren't there.
And they were not very much encouraged.
Their use was not very encouraged in astrophysics, at least in my experience.
It was quite unusual.
to have somebody like Bill Sinton actually working at two microns.

And early on, I know when I went to graduate school at Michigan, we were concentrated so heavily on the visible and near ultraviolet and near infrared, because that's where all the spectrum lines of interest were in the stellar atmospheres at that temperature range that
We just didn't really pay much attention to the infrared at all, and yet that's exactly the kind of area you need to be in when you're doing planetary astronomy.
High Spinrat and I used to and still do refer to H-alpha, which of course is in the red region of the spectrum, as the Mount Wilson infrared.
Oh, yeah.
No, that's it.
I mean, High's work on water vapor in...
the late type stars was almost pioneering work in those days.
Very, very important kind of thing to be done.
And it just, a lot of people didn't do that.
I mean, they were just happy with the information they were getting, the physics that they knew in the visible.
And I think that probably had...
That was why planetary astronomers couldn't do anything except take pictures and look at them.
There just wasn't the ability to measure small parts of the planetary disk photoelectrically.
Well, I remember going at McDonald when the Anobi came out while I was on an observing run, and so the spectrograph was all set up to work in the relatively near infrared.
So we got some spectrum, we looked up tables, lists of lines in Novi, and they occasionally would get out to H-alpha, but usually they'd stop before even that.
I mean, just start out from 30-some hundred angstroms, they'd go out to 5,500 or 6,000 or something, and then just plain stop.

You know, in our day when we went to graduate school, the panchromatic plates that went out to the red were even relatively new and often not the plate of choice if you could get away with stopping at 5,000 angstroms.
And I think that colored our approach to everything for so long that it was almost a disaster.
Okay, Peter Boyce has one great story.
Well,
Maybe more.
What I meant was one hell of a story.
Back in the late 60s, there was this phenomenon of brightening of the Jovian satellites upon reappearance from eclipse.
And sometimes it would happen and sometimes it wouldn't.
And people, because of the nearby presence of Jupiter, and it was a very difficult observation to make,
We did some observations with an area scanner, which in fact showed that the satellite was in fact a lot brighter immediately after it came out of eclipse.
But again, it didn't always happen.
So anyway, the story is that we were going to look at a reappearance with Kent Ford's infrared image tube, and that went up to
one micron, basically, on a spectrograph.
You mentioned the name of the satellite.
EO, I believe.
And so we got all together, and Kent Ford and I got the spectrograph loaded in the back end of the truck, and we were on our way out to Anderson Mesa because where the telescope was located, and...

had to get up the hill, get the telescope on, and get ready for this reappearance, which was scheduled for about 10 o'clock in the evening, because we were going to try to get a spectrum immediately after it came out from the shadow of Jupiter.
Well, at that point, we had the observatory talk the county into repaving the road
to go up to Anderson Mesa.
Part of the sealing wax and bailing wire approach, you get other people to do as much of the work as you can.
And so they agreed to take on the maintenance of the road, but only if we widened it, or it was widened.
So they were in the process of widening this road, and there was a big, fat, dough-belly-type construction foreman for the county highway department
And they had just blown 300 yards of the old road away.
We arrived at the bottom of the hill and wanted to get up to the top of the mesa and there was no other way to get up to the top of the mesa.
And so we were raging up and down trying to explain to this guy who couldn't give a hoot, you know, about why it was so important to get up there.
He said, can't you take your observations tomorrow night?
We'll have it all bulldozed out and the road pioneered back for you by then.
No.
He said, tonight we have an eclipse and we tried to explain that it's
The moon is coming out from behind Jupiter, and we have to catch it right as it comes out.
And this only happens once a month or something like that.
And the guy thought some more.
We've got a hell of a lot of rock there.
He said, I don't know if we can pioneer a road through or not.
He says, you know, is that your instrument on the back of the truck?
Pointing to the spectrograph, which was sitting there.
He said, yeah, that's it.
He says, well, why the hell don't you just fuck around with it down here?
He says, why do you have to go all the way to the top of the hill?
And he says, no, we've got to have the telescope.
So he got on.
He put overtime on.
And they pioneered a road up to the top of the hill.
We got the telescope on and fired up and the image tube working and everything going 15 minutes before the appearance.
It was absolutely spectacular.
And of course, the appearance, the spectra did not show any different changes in it.
How did that eventually turn out?
Was that just an instrumental artifact?
No, it turns out to have been the volcanism.
Frost, when you lose a little bit of the heat of the sun, things frosted over and the albedo did in fact change.
But if you didn't have fresh volcanic ejecta, then this wouldn't happen.
So that's the intermittent character.
It was the new sulfur that did it.
And of course, we couldn't find that in one micron specter.
to have this old guy with his belly hanging over his belt.
Couldn't you just fuck around with it down here?
